Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Nucleation of Calcium Phosphate Biomaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: This collaborative awards funded by the Biomaterials program of the Division of Materials Research to Washington University in St. Louis and Columbia University will investigate calcium phosphate (CaP) based biomineral formation under physiological conditions. A better understanding of real-time CaP mineral formation on collagen is required for treating mineralization-related bone pathologies, in enhancing bone regeneration, and in improving tendon-to-bone healing. Thus, the findings from the project will be important in understanding the compatibility and strength of bioactive bone and tendon-to-bone substitutes. In addition, the project will provide key information in remediating pathologic bone formation. The results will also be broadly applicable in the bio-mineralization field and will be of interest to investigators studying fundamental processes and developing regenerative medicine applications (e.g., in vitro synthesis of artificial bone materials). Furthermore, transformative knowledge obtained from this work will be applicable in many biological, medical, industrial, geological, and environmental processes. The proposed education and outreach plan will also provide educational and research opportunities for middle school, high school, undergraduate and graduate students, while simultaneously encouraging the participation and educational stimulation of students from traditionally underrepresented groups. The project team will collaborate with middle school teachers in the St. Louis area and outreach educators at Washington University's Institute for School Partnership (ISP). The team will develop workshops and free educational kits on crystal formation, and provide insight into the relevance of the experiments for bone formation. The educational kits will be available for teachers in the Greater St. Louis area, and listed on the ISP website for better dissemination.

Technical: This collaborative project will examine the initial nucleation and growth of calcium phosphate (CaP) biominerals within collagen fibrils, with consideration of the multiple length scales involved (i.e., macro-scale extrafibrillar structures and nano-scale intrafibrillar regions). Using synchrotron-based in situ real-time small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), the work will, for the first time, provide quantitative information on particle dimensions and volumes, nucleation rates, and interfacial free energies between CaP nuclei and collagen fibrils at nucleation sites. In situ wide angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) and high resolution X-ray pair-distribution functions (PDF) will examine the kinetics of multiple CaP crystallization pathways, involving both classical and non-classical nucleation behaviors, depending on the sequence of mineralization at multiple nucleation sites. Once a better understanding of nucleation kinetics and mechanisms at different nucleation sites is achieved, the project will study the consequent mechanical properties of the final products of collagen-CaP composites. By developing a novel structure-function relationship model, the project can provide a guideline for the development of better biomaterials. The technical impacts of the project encompass both fundamental scientific discovery and applications for mineralized biomaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Nucleation of calcium phosphate biomaterials. Period: September 1, 2016 to August 31, 2020; $90,000. Prof. Thomopoulos received an NSF grant (DMR-1608554) to investigate the kinetics of calcium phosphate mineralization of collagen. In particular, this project studies fluid chemical, electrical, and strain factors affecting the nucleation, growth, and crystallization of CaP minerals in collagen. 

Intellectual Merit: Appropriate mineralization of collagen is critical for the formation of many structural tissues, including bones, teeth, and attachments between connective tissues and bone. Thus, a better understanding of calcium phosphate (CaP) mineral formation on collagen is required for treating mineralization-related pathologies, enhancing bone regeneration, improving tendon-to-bone healing, and developing better biomaterials. Key accomplishments from this project include the following: 

(1)    We proved two distinct CaP nucleation pathways exist for collagen mineralization, depending on the scale of the nucleation sites (extrafibrillar and intrafibrillar mineralization). 

(2)    We elucidated the influence of nucleation pathways and sites on macroscale CaP distribution and the consequent mechanical properties of tissue-level constructs. 

(3)    We provided quantitative information on nucleation energy barriers for intrafibrillar mineralization and developed a new classical nucleation theory model by considering the confined geometry of collagen. 

(4)    By utilizing external pulsed electric stimulation and strain-generated potentials, we provided useful information for finding better strategies for treating mineralization-related pathologies, enhancing bone regeneration, and improving tendon-to-bone healing.

The project’s findings call for more attention to understanding nucleation behaviors in biomaterials. By showing the significant influence of nucleation patterns on the distribution of CaP minerals in collagen matrix, we highlighted the importance of the initial nucleation (nanoscale) on the subsequent mechanical properties of constructs (macroscale). The project clearly demonstrated that a proper consideration of the extents of extra- and intrafibrillar mineralization is needed to evaluate the construct’s mechanical properties, such as its elastic modulus, in addition to its total mineral contents.

Overall, this project has resulted in four high impact publications, including one in Nature Communications, withone more manuscript in review, and 9 invited and 10 contributed presentations at universities and conferences. The project also provided scientific insights supporting one patent application regarding phosphorus recovery from phosphorus-rich environments. To conduct the research, we made successful proposals for 17 synchrotron-based X-ray beamtime allocations at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory, IL. 

Broader Impacts: This research is closely related to surface chemistry aspects of materials science, biogeochemistry, and biomedical applications. Recently, nucleation in a confined space has been highly emphasized because many materials show properties at nanoscale that are clearly distinct from their properties in bulk. This project enhances our knowledge about mineral deposition on microscale extrafibrillar and nanoscale intrafibrillar nucleation sites in nanoconfined collagen matrices. Our biomineralization work published in Nature Communications has been featured in several media, including ‘EurekaAlert!’ from the American Association for the Advancement of Science. It was also highlighted on the opening page of the NSF website. The bioinspired phosphorus management strategy was developed as an outreach education program for young students. The program was successfully used in February 2018 and 2019 during the Women in STEM event at Washington University, where we offered hands-on workshops for more than 100 female high school students and teachers. Over four years of the project, Professor Jun’s team trained four Ph.D. students. Professor Thomopoulos’ team trained two Ph.D. students associated with this project. All participating Ph.D. students in the Jun group were trained in in situ SAXS/WAXS measurements and data analyses, sample preparations, and complementary ex situcharacterization of the samples. They also learned to handle biological samples for staining, imaging, and sectioning, and to conduct mechanical tests of soft tissue samples for uniaxial tensile stress. In addition, the work offered research opportunities to two high school students and four undergraduate students, who were trained to make CaP structures using organic templates to uptake phosphate ions.
